news_summary: Today’s space news highlights NASA's advancing exploration with the upcoming Artemis II Moon mission, innovative support for the Dragonfly mission, new satellite technologies like Pandora and CubeSats to study exoplanets, and the launch of a unique radar satellite to monitor Earth’s surface.
news_summary_fr: Les actualités spatiales d'aujourd'hui mettent en avant les progrès de la NASA en matière d'exploration avec la prochaine mission lunaire Artemis II, le soutien innovant apporté à la mission Dragonfly, les nouvelles technologies satellitaires telles que Pandora et CubeSats pour étudier les exoplanètes, et le lancement d'un satellite radar unique destiné à surveiller la surface de la Terre.
news_summary_es: Las noticias espaciales de hoy destacan los avances de la NASA en materia de exploración con la próxima misión lunar Artemis II, el innovador apoyo a la misión Dragonfly, las nuevas tecnologías satelitales como Pandora y CubeSats para estudiar exoplanetas, y el lanzamiento de un satélite radar único para monitorear la superficie terrestre.

articles.title: When does the Nasa Moon mission launch and who are the Artemis II crew?
articles.summary: The first crewed Moon mission in 50 years could launch in February, preparing the way for a future landing.
articles.content:
When does the Nasa Moon mission launch and who are the Artemis II crew?

9 hours ago Share Save Pallab Ghosh , Science Correspondent and Alison Francis Share Save

NASA Artemis II Crew: left Christina Koch, back Victor Glover (pilot), front Reid Wiseman (commander), right Jeremy Hansen

The first crewed Moon mission in more than 50 years could be launched by Nasa as soon as the first week of February. The Artemis II mission, which will last about 10 days, could take its astronauts further into space than anyone has been before. It aims to set the stage for an eventual human landing on the lunar surface for the first time since the Apollo missions of the 1960s and 70s.

When does Artemis II launch?

Nasa's planned launch window opens on 6 February and runs into the spring. The US space agency wants the rocket to blast off before the end of April. A date will not be set until final checks on its Space Launch System (SLS) rocket, the Orion capsule - which carries the crew - and ground systems are completed. The mission will be launched from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida.

Who are the Artemis II crew and what will they be doing?

Artemis II's crew of four includes Nasa's commander Reid Wiseman, pilot Victor Glover and mission specialist Christina Koch. A second mission specialist, Jeremy Hansen of the Canadian Space Agency, will also be on board. The mission involves the first crewed flight of SLS and Orion. Once they are safely in orbit, the astronauts will test how the Orion spacecraft handles. This will involve manually flying the capsule in Earth orbit to practise steering and lining up the spacecraft for future Moon landings. They will then head out to a point thousands of kilometres beyond the Moon to check Orion's life‑support, propulsion, power and navigation systems. The crew will also act as medical test subjects, sending back data and imagery from deep space. They will work in a small cabin in weightlessness. Radiation levels will be higher than on the International Space Station, which is in low‑Earth orbit, but still safe. On return to Earth, the astronauts will experience a bumpy return through the atmosphere and a splashdown off the west coast of the US, in the Pacific.

Will Artemis II land on the Moon?

No. This mission is to lay the ground for a lunar landing by astronauts in the Artemis III mission. Nasa says the launch of Artemis III will take place "no earlier than" 2027. However, experts believe 2028 is the earliest possible date. The final choice of a spacecraft to take the crew down to the lunar surface has not yet been made. It will either be SpaceX's Starship lander or a craft designed by Jeff Bezos's Blue Origin. New spacesuits made by US company Axiom are also not ready. When Artemis III finally flies, the astronauts will be heading to the Moon's south pole. After this, the aim is to have a sustained human presence on the Moon. Artemis IV and V will begin building Gateway, a small space station circling the Moon. After that, there will be more Moon landings, extra sections added to Gateway, and new robotic rovers on the surface. More countries will be involved in keeping people living and working on and around the Moon for longer periods.

When was the last Moon mission?

The last crewed Moon mission was Apollo 17, which landed in December 1972 and returned to Earth later that month. In all, 24 astronauts have travelled to the Moon and 12 of them have walked on its surface, all during the Apollo programme. America first went in the 1960s, primarily to beat the Soviet Union to assert its geopolitical and technological dominance. Once that goal was achieved, political enthusiasm and public interest ebbed, as did the money for future Moonshots. Artemis grew out of a desire to return humans to the Moon, this time for a longer-term presence built around new technology and commercial partnerships.

Do other countries plan to send astronauts to the Moon?

Several other countries have ambitions to put people on the Moon in the 2030s.​ European astronauts are set to join later Artemis missions and Japan has also secured seats. China is building its own craft, targeting a first landing near the Moon's south pole by 2030. Russia continues to talk about flying cosmonauts to the surface and building a small base sometime between about 2030 and 2035. Sanctions, funding pressures and technical setbacks mean its timetable is highly optimistic. India has also expressed ambitions to one day see its own astronauts walking on the Moon. Following the success of Chandrayaan 3's landing near the lunar south pole, India's space agency set out a goal of sending astronauts to the Moon by about 2040. This would be part of a push to move its human spaceflight programme beyond low Earth orbit.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on the upcoming Artemis II mission, the first crewed Moon mission in over 50 years, which represents a significant milestone in human space exploration. It details the mission's objectives, crew, and its role in paving the way for sustained human presence on the Moon, with broad implications for international cooperation and future space endeavors.
articles.personality_title: NASA's Artemis II set to launch first crewed Moon mission in over 50 years
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – NASA is preparing to send astronauts on a mission around the Moon for the first time since the 1970s. This mission, called Artemis II, will help test new space technologies and prepare for future Moon landings.

**What happened** – NASA plans to launch Artemis II as early as February 6, 2024, from Kennedy Space Center in Florida. Four astronauts—Reid Wiseman (commander), Victor Glover (pilot), Christina Koch (mission specialist), and Jeremy Hansen from the Canadian Space Agency—will travel farther into space than anyone has before. They will test the Orion spacecraft’s systems by flying around Earth and then moving thousands of kilometers beyond the Moon before returning to Earth.

**Impact** – This mission is important because it is the first crewed flight of NASA’s new Space Launch System rocket and Orion capsule. It will check that the spacecraft can support humans in deep space and help prepare for Artemis III, which aims to land astronauts on the Moon’s south pole for the first time since 1972. Artemis II will also provide valuable information about living and working in space, including how astronauts handle weightlessness and radiation.

**What's next step** – After Artemis II, NASA plans Artemis III, expected no earlier than 2027 or 2028, which will attempt to land astronauts on the Moon. Future missions will build a space station called Gateway around the Moon and involve international partners like Europe, Japan, China, Russia, and India, all aiming to explore and live on the Moon more regularly.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Artemis II will test new space systems with astronauts orbiting the Moon, paving the way for future Moon landings and longer human missions beyond Earth.
articles.personality_title_fr: Artemis II de la NASA : première mission habitée vers la Lune en plus de 50 ans
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La NASA se prépare à envoyer des astronautes en mission autour de la Lune pour la première fois depuis les années 1970. Cette mission, appelée Artemis II, permettra de tester de nouvelles technologies spatiales et de préparer les futurs atterrissages lunaires.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – La NASA prévoit de lancer Artemis II dès le 6 février 2024 depuis le Kennedy Space Center en Floride. Quatre astronautes – Reid Wiseman (commandant), Victor Glover (pilote), Christina Koch (spécialiste de mission) et Jeremy Hansen de l’Agence spatiale canadienne – voyageront plus loin dans l’espace que personne auparavant. Ils testeront les systèmes du vaisseau Orion en volant autour de la Terre puis en s’éloignant de plusieurs milliers de kilomètres au-delà de la Lune avant de revenir sur Terre.

**Impact** – Cette mission est importante car c’est le premier vol habité du nouveau lanceur Space Launch System de la NASA et du vaisseau Orion. Elle vérifiera si le vaisseau peut soutenir des humains dans l’espace lointain et préparera Artemis III, qui vise à poser des astronautes sur le pôle sud de la Lune pour la première fois depuis 1972. Artemis II fournira aussi des données précieuses sur la vie en apesanteur et l’exposition aux radiations.

**Prochaine étape** – Après Artemis II, la NASA prévoit Artemis III, prévue au plus tôt en 2027 ou 2028, qui tentera d’atterrir sur la Lune. Les missions suivantes construiront une station spatiale appelée Gateway autour de la Lune et impliqueront des partenaires internationaux comme l’Europe, le Japon, la Chine, la Russie et l’Inde, tous visant à explorer et habiter la Lune plus régulièrement.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Artemis II testera de nouveaux systèmes spatiaux avec des astronautes en orbite lunaire, préparant les futures missions lunaires et les séjours humains prolongés au-delà de la Terre.
articles.personality_title_es: Artemis II de la NASA: primera misión tripulada a la Luna en más de 50 años
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La NASA se prepara para enviar astronautas en una misión alrededor de la Luna por primera vez desde la década de 1970. Esta misión, llamada Artemis II, ayudará a probar nuevas tecnologías espaciales y a preparar futuros aterrizajes en la Luna.

**Qué pasó** – La NASA planea lanzar Artemis II tan pronto como el 6 de febrero de 2024 desde el Centro Espacial Kennedy en Florida. Cuatro astronautas—Reid Wiseman (comandante), Victor Glover (piloto), Christina Koch (especialista de misión) y Jeremy Hansen de la Agencia Espacial Canadiense—viajarán más lejos en el espacio que nadie antes. Probarán los sistemas de la nave Orion al volar alrededor de la Tierra y luego alejarse miles de kilómetros más allá de la Luna antes de regresar a la Tierra.

**Impacto** – Esta misión es importante porque es el primer vuelo tripulado del nuevo cohete Space Launch System y la cápsula Orion de la NASA. Comprobará que la nave puede apoyar a humanos en el espacio profundo y preparará Artemis III, que intentará aterrizar astronautas en el polo sur de la Luna por primera vez desde 1972. Artemis II también proporcionará información valiosa sobre cómo vivir y trabajar en el espacio, incluyendo cómo los astronautas manejan la ingravidez y la radiación.

**Próximo paso** – Después de Artemis II, la NASA planea Artemis III, esperado no antes de 2027 o 2028, que intentará aterrizar en la Luna. Las misiones futuras construirán una estación espacial llamada Gateway alrededor de la Luna e involucrarán socios internacionales como Europa, Japón, China, Rusia e India, que buscan explorar y vivir en la Luna con más frecuencia.

**Resumen en una frase** – Artemis II probará nuevos sistemas espaciales con astronautas orbitando la Luna, preparando el camino para futuros aterrizajes lunares y misiones humanas más largas más allá de la Tierra.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed painting of a sleek, stylized spacecraft orbiting a softly glowing, cratered Moon with four distinct, gently illuminated silhouettes inside representing astronauts, set against a vast, deep space backdrop with warm, muted earth tones and subtle hints of blue and gray to evoke calm exploration and pioneering spirit.

articles.title: Flight Engineers Give NASA’s Dragonfly Lift
articles.summary: In sending a car-sized rotorcraft to explore Saturn’s moon Titan, NASA’s Dragonfly mission will undertake an unprecedented voyage of scientific discovery. And the work to ensure that this first-of-its-kind project can fulfill its ambitious exploration vision is underway in some of the nation’s most advanced space simulation and testing laboratories. Set for launch in in […]
articles.content:
In sending a car-sized rotorcraft to explore Saturn’s moon Titan, NASA’s Dragonfly mission will undertake an unprecedented voyage of scientific discovery. And the work to ensure that this first-of-its-kind project can fulfill its ambitious exploration vision is underway in some of the nation’s most advanced space simulation and testing laboratories.

From left, Johns Hopkins APL engineers Tyler Radomsky and Felipe Ruiz install a rotor on the Dragonfly test model at the Transonic Dynamics Tunnel at NASA’s Langley Research Center in Virginia. NASA

Set for launch in in 2028, the Dragonfly rotorcraft is being designed and built at the Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Laboratory (APL) in Laurel, Maryland, with contributions from organizations around the world. On arrival in 2034, Dragonfly will exploit Titan’s dense atmosphere and low gravity to fly to dozens of locations, exploring varied environments from organic equatorial dunes to an impact crater where liquid water and complex organic materials essential to life (at least as we know it) may have existed together.

Aerodynamic testing

When full rotorcraft integration and testing begins in February, the team will tap into a trove of data gathered through critical technical trials conducted over the past three years, including, most recently, two campaigns at the Transonic Dynamics Tunnel (TDT) facility at NASA’s Langley Research Center in Hampton, Virginia.

From left, Charles Pheng, Ryan Miller, John Kayrouz, Kristen Carey and Josie Ward prepare for the first aeromechanical performance tests of the full-scale Dragonfly rotors in the Transonic Dynamics Tunnel at NASA’s Langley Research Center in Virginia. NASA

The TDT is a versatile 16-foot-high, 16-foot-wide, 20-foot-long testing hub that has hosted studies for NASA, the Department of War, the aircraft industry and an array of universities.

Over five weeks, from August into September, the team evaluated the performance of Dragonfly’s rotor system – which provides the lift for the lander to fly and enables it to maneuver – in Titan-like conditions, looking at aeromechanical performance factors such as stress on the rotor arms, and effects of vibration on the rotor blades and lander body. In late December, the team also wrapped up a set of aerodynamics tests on smaller-scale Dragonfly rotor models in the TDT.

“When Dragonfly enters the atmosphere at Titan and parachutes deploy after the heat shield does its job, the rotors are going to have to work perfectly the first time,” said Dave Piatak, branch chief for aeroelasticity at NASA Langley. “There’s no room for error, so any concerns with vehicle structural dynamics or aerodynamics need to be known now and tested on the ground. With the Transonic Dynamics Tunnel here at Langley, NASA offers just the right capability for the Dragonfly team to gather this critical data.”

Critical parts

In his three years as an experimental machinist at APL, Cory Pennington has crafted parts for projects dispatched around the globe. But fashioning rotors for a drone to explore another world in our solar system? That was new – and a little daunting.

“The rotors are some of the most important parts on Dragonfly,” Pennington said. “Without the rotors, it doesn’t fly – and it doesn’t meet its mission objectives at Titan.”

Experimental machinist Cory Pennington examines a freshly milled, full-scale Dragonfly rotor in the machine shop at the Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Laboratory (APL) in Laurel, Maryland. NASA/Johns Hopkins APL

Pennington and team cut Dragonfly’s first rotors on Nov. 1, 2024. They refined the process as they went: starting with waterjet paring of 1,000-pound aluminum blocks, followed by rough machining, cover fitting, vent-hole drilling and hole-threading. After an inspection, the parts were cleaned, sent out for welding and returned for final finishing.

“We didn’t have time or materials to make test parts or extras, so every cut had to be right the first time,” Pennington said, adding that the team also had to find special tools and equipment to accommodate some material changes and design tweaks.

The team was able to deliver the parts a month early. Engineers set up and spin-tested the rotors at APL – attached to a full-scale model representing half of the Dragonfly lander – before transporting the entire package to the TDT at NASA Langley in late July.

“On Titan, we’ll control the speeds of Dragonfly’s different rotors to induce forward flight, climbs, descents and turns,” said Felipe Ruiz, lead Dragonfly rotor engineer at APL.

“It’s a complicated geometry going to a flight environment that we are still learning about. So the wind tunnel tests are one of the most important venues for us to demonstrate the design.”

And the rotors passed the tests.

“Not only did the tests validate the design team’s approach, we’ll use all that data to create high-fidelity representations of loads, forces and dynamics that help us predict Dragonfly’s performance on Titan with a high degree of confidence,” said Rick Heisler, wind tunnel test lead from APL.

Next, the rotors will undergo fatigue and cryogenic trials under simulated Titan conditions, where the temperature is minus 290 degrees Fahrenheit (minus 178 degrees Celsius), before building the actual flight rotors.

“We’re not just cutting metal — we’re fabricating something that’s going to another world,” Pennington said. “It’s incredible to know that what we build will fly on Titan.”

Collaboration, innovation

Elizabeth “Zibi” Turtle, Dragonfly principal investigator at APL, says the latest work in the TDT demonstrates the mission’s innovation, ingenuity and collaboration across government and industry.

“The team worked well together, under time pressure, to develop solutions, assess design decisions, and execute fabrication and testing,” she said. “There’s still much to do between now and our launch in 2028, but everyone who worked on this should take tremendous pride in these accomplishments that make it possible for Dragonfly to fly on Titan.”

To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that

supports HTML5 video When NASA's Dragonfly begins full rotorcraft integration and testing in early 2026, the mission team will tap into a trove of data gathered through critical technical trials conducted over the past three years, including, most recently, a testing campaign in at the Transonic Dynamics Tunnel (TDT) Facility at NASA’s Langley Research Center in Hampton, Virginia. NASA/Johns Hopkins APL

Dragonfly has been a collaborative effort from the start. Kenneth Hibbard, mission systems engineer from APL, cites the vertical-lift expertise of Penn State University on the initial rotor design, aero-related modeling and analysis, and testing support in the TDT, as well as NASA Langley’s 14-by-22-foot Subsonic Tunnel. Sikorsky Aircraft of Connecticut has also supported aeromechanics and aerodynamics testing and analysis, as well as flight hardware modeling and simulation.

The Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Laboratory (APL) in Laurel, Maryland, leads the Dragonfly mission for NASA in collaboration with several NASA centers, industry partners, academic institutions and international space agencies. Elizabeth “Zibi” Turtle of APL is the principal investigator. Dragonfly is part of NASA’s New Frontiers Program, managed by the Planetary Missions Program Office at NASA Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Alabama, for the agency’s Science Mission Directorate in Washington.

For more information on NASA’s Dragonfly mission, visit:

https://science.nasa.gov/mission/dragonfly/

by Mike Buckley

Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Laboratory

MEDIA CONTACTS:

Karen Fox / Molly Wasser

Headquarters, Washington

240-285-5155 / 240-419-1732

karen.c.fox@nasa.gov / molly.l.wasser@nasa.gov

Joe Atkinson

NASA’s Langley Research Center, Hampton, Virginia

757-755-5375

joseph.s.atkinson@nasa.gov

Mike Buckley

Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Laboratory, Laurel, Maryland

443-567-3145

michael.buckley@jhuapl.edu
articles.reasoning: The article details NASA's Dragonfly mission to Titan, highlighting significant technological and scientific advancements with broad implications for space exploration and understanding of potentially life-supporting environments beyond Earth. It focuses on a single major project with detailed context about its development, testing, and collaborative innovation, representing a meaningful and inspiring breakthrough in space technology and exploration.
articles.personality_title: NASA's Dragonfly rotors pass key tests for mission to Saturn’s moon Titan
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – NASA is preparing a mission called Dragonfly, a drone-like rotorcraft about the size of a car, to explore Titan, Saturn’s largest moon. Titan has a thick atmosphere and low gravity, making it possible for Dragonfly to fly across its surface and study different areas that might have once supported life.

**What happened** – Engineers at Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Laboratory built and tested Dragonfly’s rotors, the spinning blades that will lift and move the craft. They used NASA’s Transonic Dynamics Tunnel in Virginia to simulate Titan-like conditions, checking how the rotors handle stress, vibration, and airflow. The tests showed the rotors work as planned. The team also made the first full-size rotors from special aluminum, carefully cutting and shaping them to exact standards.

**Impact** – These successful tests are important because Dragonfly’s rotors must work perfectly on Titan, where repairs are impossible. The data collected helps scientists predict how the craft will fly in Titan’s cold, dense atmosphere. This mission is the first of its kind to send a flying vehicle to another world, opening new ways to explore planets and moons.

**What's next step** – The rotors will soon face more tests, including ones that simulate Titan’s extremely cold temperatures. After that, the team will build the actual flight-ready rotors. Full assembly and testing of the Dragonfly craft will begin in 2026, with launch planned for 2028 and arrival at Titan in 2034.

**One-sentence takeaway** – NASA’s Dragonfly mission has passed crucial rotor tests that bring it closer to flying across Titan and exploring new worlds beyond Earth.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les rotors de Dragonfly de la NASA réussissent des tests clés pour la mission sur Titan, lune de Saturne
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La NASA prépare une mission appelée Dragonfly, un drone de la taille d’une voiture, pour explorer Titan, la plus grande lune de Saturne. Titan possède une atmosphère dense et une faible gravité, ce qui permet à Dragonfly de voler à travers sa surface et d’étudier différentes zones qui ont peut-être déjà accueilli la vie.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des ingénieurs du laboratoire de physique appliquée de Johns Hopkins ont construit et testé les rotors de Dragonfly, les pales tournantes qui soulèveront et déplaceront l’engin. Ils ont utilisé le tunnel de dynamique transsonique de la NASA en Virginie pour simuler les conditions de Titan, vérifiant comment les rotors supportent le stress, les vibrations et le flux d’air. Les tests ont montré que les rotors fonctionnent comme prévu. L’équipe a aussi fabriqué les premiers rotors à taille réelle en aluminium spécial, les découpant et façonnant avec précision.

**Impact** – Ces tests réussis sont importants car les rotors de Dragonfly doivent fonctionner parfaitement sur Titan, où aucune réparation n’est possible. Les données recueillies aident les scientifiques à prévoir le vol de l’engin dans l’atmosphère froide et dense de Titan. Cette mission est la première de ce type à envoyer un véhicule volant sur un autre monde, ouvrant de nouvelles façons d’explorer planètes et lunes.

**Prochaines étapes** – Les rotors seront bientôt soumis à d’autres tests, notamment pour simuler les températures extrêmement froides de Titan. Ensuite, l’équipe construira les rotors prêts pour le vol. L’assemblage complet et les tests de Dragonfly commenceront en 2026, avec un lancement prévu en 2028 et une arrivée sur Titan en 2034.

**Résumé en une phrase** – La mission Dragonfly de la NASA a réussi des tests cruciaux de ses rotors, la rapprochant du vol sur Titan et de l’exploration de nouveaux mondes au-delà de la Terre.
articles.personality_title_es: Los rotores de Dragonfly de la NASA superan pruebas clave para la misión a Titán, luna de Saturno
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La NASA está preparando una misión llamada Dragonfly, un vehículo parecido a un dron del tamaño de un coche, para explorar Titán, la luna más grande de Saturno. Titán tiene una atmósfera densa y baja gravedad, lo que permitirá a Dragonfly volar por su superficie y estudiar diferentes zonas que podrían haber tenido condiciones para la vida.

**Qué pasó** – Ingenieros del Laboratorio de Física Aplicada de Johns Hopkins construyeron y probaron los rotores de Dragonfly, las aspas que levantarán y moverán la nave. Usaron el Túnel de Dinámica Transónica de la NASA en Virginia para simular las condiciones de Titán, revisando cómo los rotores soportan el estrés, las vibraciones y el flujo de aire. Las pruebas mostraron que los rotores funcionan según lo planeado. También fabricaron los primeros rotores a tamaño real con aluminio especial, cortándolos y moldeándolos con precisión.

**Impacto** – Estas pruebas exitosas son importantes porque los rotores de Dragonfly deben funcionar perfectamente en Titán, donde no se pueden hacer reparaciones. Los datos ayudan a los científicos a predecir cómo volará la nave en la fría y densa atmósfera de Titán. Esta misión es la primera que enviará un vehículo volador a otro mundo, abriendo nuevas formas de explorar planetas y lunas.

**Próximos pasos** – Los rotores pasarán más pruebas, incluyendo simulaciones de las temperaturas extremadamente frías de Titán. Luego, el equipo construirá los rotores listos para el vuelo. El ensamblaje completo y las pruebas de Dragonfly comenzarán en 2026, con lanzamiento previsto para 2028 y llegada a Titán en 2034.

**Resumen en una frase** – La misión Dragonfly de la NASA ha superado pruebas clave de sus rotores, acercándola a volar sobre Titán y explorar nuevos mundos más allá de la Tierra.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm-toned painting of a large, intricate rotorcraft model with spinning rotors suspended mid-air inside a spacious, softly lit wind tunnel, surrounded by abstract silhouettes of engineers symbolized as gentle glowing hands carefully adjusting and supporting the rotor arms, with subtle hints of Saturn and Titan’s hazy orange atmosphere visible through a distant window, all rendered in natural, muted earth and metal tones.

articles.title: NASA’s Pandora Satellite, CubeSats to Explore Exoplanets, Beyond
articles.summary: A new NASA spacecraft called Pandora is awaiting launch ahead of its journey to study the atmospheres of exoplanets, or worlds beyond our solar system, and their stars. Along for the ride are two shoebox-sized satellites called BlackCAT (Black Hole Coded Aperture Telescope) and SPARCS (Star-Planet Activity Research CubeSat), as NASA innovates with ambitious science […]
articles.content:
A new NASA spacecraft called Pandora is awaiting launch ahead of its journey to study the atmospheres of exoplanets, or worlds beyond our solar system, and their stars.

Along for the ride are two shoebox-sized satellites called BlackCAT (Black Hole Coded Aperture Telescope) and SPARCS (Star-Planet Activity Research CubeSat), as NASA innovates with ambitious science missions that take low-cost, creative approaches to answering questions like, “How does the universe work?” and “Are we alone?”

All three missions are set to launch Jan. 11 on a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket from Space Launch Complex 4 East at Vandenberg Space Force Base in California. The launch window opens at 8:19 a.m. EST (5:19 a.m. PST). SpaceX will livestream the event.

Artist’s concept of NASA’s Pandora mission, which will help scientists untangle the signals from the atmospheres of exoplanets — worlds beyond our solar system — and their stars. NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center/Conceptual Image Lab

“Pandora’s goal is to disentangle the atmospheric signals of planets and stars using visible and near-infrared light,” said Elisa Quintana, Pandora’s principal investigator at NASA’s Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Maryland. “This information can help astronomers determine if detected elements and compounds are coming from the star or the planet — an important step as we search for signs of life in the cosmos.”

BlackCAT and SPARCS are small satellites that will study the transient, high-energy universe and the activity of low-mass stars, respectively.

Pandora will observe planets as they pass in front of their stars as seen from our perspective, events called transits.

As starlight passes through a planet’s atmosphere, it interacts with substances like water and oxygen that absorb characteristic wavelengths, adding their chemical fingerprints to the signal.

But while only a small fraction of the star’s light grazes the planet, telescopes also collect the rest of the light emitted by the star’s facing side. Stellar surfaces can sport brighter and darker regions that grow, shrink, and change position over time, suppressing or magnifying signals from planetary atmospheres. Adding a further complication, some of these areas may contain the same chemicals that astronomers hope to find in the planet’s atmosphere, such as water vapor.

All these factors make it difficult to be certain that important detected molecules come from the planet alone.

Pandora will help address this problem by providing in-depth study of at least 20 exoplanets and their host stars during its initial year. The satellite will look at each planet and its star 10 times, with each observation lasting a total of 24 hours. Many of these worlds are among the over 6,000 discovered by missions like NASA’s TESS (Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite).

This view of the fully integrated Pandora spacecraft was taken May 19, 2025, following the mission’s successful environmental test campaign at Blue Canyon Technologies in Lafayette, Colorado. Visible are star trackers (center), multilayer insulation blankets (white), the end of the telescope (top), and the solar panel (right) in its launch configuration. NASA/BCT

Pandora will collect visible and near-infrared light using a novel, all-aluminum 17-inch-wide (45-centimeter) telescope jointly developed by Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California and Corning Incorporated in Keene, New Hampshire. Pandora’s near-infrared detector is a spare developed for NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope.

Each long observation period will capture a star’s light both before and during a transit and help determine how stellar surface features impact measurements.

“These intense studies of individual systems are difficult to schedule on high-demand missions, like Webb,” said engineer Jordan Karburn, Pandora’s deputy project manager at Livermore. “You also need the simultaneous multiwavelength measurements to pick out the star’s signal from the planet’s. The long stares with both detectors are critical for tracing the exact origins of elements and compounds scientists consider indicators of potential habitability.”

Pandora is the first satellite to launch in the agency’s Astrophysics Pioneers program, which seeks to do compelling astrophysics at a lower cost while training the next generation of leaders in space science.

After launching into low Earth orbit, Pandora will undergo a month of commissioning before embarking on its one-year prime mission. All the mission’s data will be publicly available.

“The Pandora mission is a bold new chapter in exoplanet exploration,” said Daniel Apai, an astronomy and planetary science professor at the University of Arizona in Tucson where the mission’s operations center resides. “It is the first space telescope built specifically to study, in detail, starlight filtered through exoplanet atmospheres. Pandora’s data will help scientists interpret observations from past and current missions like NASA’s Kepler and Webb space telescopes. And it will guide future projects in their search for habitable worlds.”

Watch to learn more about NASA’s Pandora mission, which will revolutionize the study of exoplanet atmospheres.

NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center

The BlackCAT and SPARCS missions will take off alongside Pandora through NASA’s Astrophysics CubeSat program, the latter supported by the Agency's CubeSat Launch Initiative.

CubeSats are a class of nanosatellites that come in sizes that are multiples of a standard cube measuring 3.9 inches (10 centimeters) across. Both BlackCAT and SPARCS are 11.8 by 7.8 by 3.9 inches (30 by 20 by 10 centimeters). CubeSats are designed to provide cost-effective access to space to test new technologies and educate early career scientists and engineers while delivering compelling science.

The BlackCAT mission will use a wide-field telescope and a novel type of X-ray detector to study powerful cosmic explosions like gamma-ray bursts, particularly those from the early universe, and other fleeting cosmic events. It will join NASA’s network of missions that watch for these changes. Abe Falcone at Pennsylvania State University in University Park, where the satellite was designed and built, leads the mission with contributions from Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico. Kongsberg NanoAvionics US provided the spacecraft bus.

The SPARCS CubeSat will monitor flares and other activity from low-mass stars using ultraviolet light to determine how they affect the space environment around orbiting planets. Evgenya Shkolnik at Arizona State University in Tempe leads the mission with participation from NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Southern California. In addition to providing science support, JPL developed the ultraviolet detectors and the associated electronics. Blue Canyon Technologies fabricated the spacecraft bus.

Pandora is led by NASA Goddard. Livermore provides the mission’s project management and engineering. Pandora’s telescope was manufactured by Corning and developed collaboratively with Livermore, which also developed the imaging detector assemblies, the mission’s control electronics, and all supporting thermal and mechanical subsystems. The near-infrared sensor was provided by NASA Goddard. Blue Canyon Technologies provided the bus and performed spacecraft assembly, integration, and environmental testing. NASA’s Ames Research Center in California’s Silicon Valley will perform the mission’s data processing. Pandora’s mission operations center is located at the University of Arizona, and a host of additional universities support the science team.

By Jeanette Kazmierczak

NASA’s Goddard Space Flight Center, Greenbelt, Md.

Media Contact:

Claire Andreoli

301-286-1940

NASA’s Goddard Space Flight Center, Greenbelt, Md.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on NASA's upcoming Pandora mission and accompanying CubeSats, which represent a significant scientific advancement in studying exoplanet atmospheres and their stars. This mission has broad implications for understanding planetary habitability and the search for life beyond Earth, impacting the general public's knowledge of the universe. The article provides detailed context about the mission's goals, technology, and collaborative efforts, fulfilling the criteria for inspiring good news.
articles.personality_title: NASA’s Pandora and CubeSats set to study distant worlds and stars
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – NASA is launching a new spacecraft called Pandora along with two small satellites, BlackCAT and SPARCS. These missions will study planets outside our solar system, called exoplanets, and their stars to learn more about their atmospheres and activity.

**What happened** – On January 11, NASA plans to launch Pandora, BlackCAT, and SPARCS on a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket from California. Pandora will observe how starlight changes as it passes through exoplanet atmospheres during events called transits. BlackCAT will study cosmic explosions like gamma-ray bursts, and SPARCS will monitor star flares using ultraviolet light.

**Impact** – Pandora is the first satellite designed specifically to separate signals from exoplanet atmospheres and their stars using visible and near-infrared light. This helps scientists tell if molecules like water come from the planet or the star, which is crucial when searching for signs of life. The CubeSats offer cost-effective ways to explore space and test new technology, while training future scientists.

**What’s next step** – After launch, Pandora will spend a month preparing before a year-long mission studying at least 20 exoplanets and their stars. All data will be shared publicly, helping scientists worldwide understand these distant worlds better and plan future space missions.

**One-sentence takeaway** – NASA’s Pandora and its companion CubeSats will provide detailed new insights into the atmospheres of distant planets and the stars they orbit, advancing our understanding of worlds beyond our solar system.
articles.personality_title_fr: Pandora et CubeSats de la NASA prêts à étudier des mondes lointains et leurs étoiles
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La NASA lance un nouveau vaisseau spatial appelé Pandora accompagné de deux petits satellites, BlackCAT et SPARCS. Ces missions étudieront des planètes en dehors de notre système solaire, appelées exoplanètes, ainsi que leurs étoiles pour mieux comprendre leurs atmosphères et leur activité.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le 11 janvier, la NASA prévoit de lancer Pandora, BlackCAT et SPARCS à bord d’une fusée SpaceX Falcon 9 depuis la Californie. Pandora observera comment la lumière des étoiles change en passant à travers les atmosphères des exoplanètes lors d’événements appelés transits. BlackCAT étudiera les explosions cosmiques comme les sursauts gamma, tandis que SPARCS surveillera les éruptions stellaires en lumière ultraviolette.

**Impact** – Pandora est le premier satellite conçu spécialement pour séparer les signaux des atmosphères d’exoplanètes de ceux de leurs étoiles en utilisant la lumière visible et proche infrarouge. Cela aide les scientifiques à savoir si des molécules comme l’eau proviennent de la planète ou de l’étoile, ce qui est essentiel pour rechercher des signes de vie. Les CubeSats offrent des moyens peu coûteux d’explorer l’espace et de tester de nouvelles technologies tout en formant les futurs scientifiques.

**Prochaine étape** – Après le lancement, Pandora passera un mois en préparation avant une mission d’un an à étudier au moins 20 exoplanètes et leurs étoiles. Toutes les données seront partagées publiquement, aidant les scientifiques du monde entier à mieux comprendre ces mondes lointains et à préparer de futures missions spatiales.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – Pandora et ses CubeSats compagnons de la NASA fourniront de nouvelles informations détaillées sur les atmosphères des planètes lointaines et les étoiles qu’elles orbitent, faisant progresser notre compréhension des mondes au-delà de notre système solaire.
articles.personality_title_es: Pandora y CubeSats de la NASA listos para estudiar mundos distantes y sus estrellas
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La NASA está lanzando una nueva nave espacial llamada Pandora junto con dos pequeños satélites, BlackCAT y SPARCS. Estas misiones estudiarán planetas fuera de nuestro sistema solar, llamados exoplanetas, y sus estrellas para aprender más sobre sus atmósferas y actividad.

**Qué pasó** – El 11 de enero, la NASA planea lanzar Pandora, BlackCAT y SPARCS en un cohete SpaceX Falcon 9 desde California. Pandora observará cómo la luz de las estrellas cambia al pasar por las atmósferas de exoplanetas durante eventos llamados tránsitos. BlackCAT estudiará explosiones cósmicas como estallidos de rayos gamma, y SPARCS monitoreará las llamaradas estelares usando luz ultravioleta.

**Impacto** – Pandora es el primer satélite diseñado específicamente para separar las señales de las atmósferas de exoplanetas y sus estrellas usando luz visible y cercana al infrarrojo. Esto ayuda a los científicos a saber si moléculas como el agua provienen del planeta o de la estrella, algo crucial para buscar signos de vida. Los CubeSats ofrecen formas económicas de explorar el espacio y probar nuevas tecnologías, mientras forman a futuros científicos.

**Próximo paso** – Después del lanzamiento, Pandora pasará un mes preparándose antes de una misión de un año estudiando al menos 20 exoplanetas y sus estrellas. Todos los datos serán compartidos públicamente, ayudando a científicos en todo el mundo a entender mejor estos mundos distantes y planear futuras misiones espaciales.

**Frase clave** – Pandora y sus CubeSats compañeros de la NASA proporcionarán nuevos detalles sobre las atmósferas de planetas distantes y las estrellas que orbitan, avanzando en nuestro conocimiento de mundos más allá de nuestro sistema solar.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm-toned painting of a sleek, futuristic satellite with a compact telescope and solar panels orbiting a glowing star, with translucent, layered rings around the star symbolizing exoplanet atmospheres being studied; nearby, two small, cube-shaped satellites float gently, emitting soft light beams that represent their scientific observations of cosmic phenomena and stellar activity, all set against a calm, dark space background with subtle hints of distant galaxies.

articles.title: 'Knitted' satellite launching to monitor Earth's surface with radar
articles.summary: A standard industrial knitting machine has been modified to produce fabrics from tungsten wire coated in gold, which are used to form the dish on the CarbSAR satellite
articles.content:
A standard industrial knitting machine has been modified to produce fabrics from tungsten wire coated in gold, which are used to form the dish on the CarbSAR satellite

An artist’s impression of CarbSAR orbiting Earth Oxford Space Systems

A new UK satellite is about to launch, wearing the latest in high‑tech knitwear. Called CarbSAR, it is due to go into orbit on Sunday, where it will deploy a mesh radar antenna produced on a machine more commonly found in a textiles factory.

“It’s a very standard, off‑the‑shelf industrial machine used for knitting jumpers. All we’ve done is add some bells and whistles to let it stitch our special yarns,” says Amool Raina, production lead at Oxford Space Systems (OSS) in the UK.

The company has partnered with another UK-based firm, Surrey Satellite Technology Limited (SSTL), to mount the antenna onto a small, inexpensive spacecraft capable of capturing high‑resolution images of Earth’s surface.

If it performs as expected, a similar novel design will be adopted for a network of surveillance satellites for the British Ministry of Defence (MoD) later this decade.

The “wool” in OSS’s knitting process is an ultra‑fine tungsten wire coated in gold. The company’s machine turns out metres of fabric at a time. These mesh sheets can be cut into pizza slice-shaped pieces and sewn together to form a 3-millimetre-wide disc that, when stretched tightly over 48 carbon‑fibre ribs, becomes a smooth parabolic dish ideal for radar imaging.

Free newsletter Sign up to Launchpad Bring the galaxy to your inbox every month, with the latest space news, launches and astronomical occurrences from New Scientist’s Leah Crane. Sign up to newsletter

A key innovation lies in the way each rib is wound radially around a central hub for launch, like 48 coiled builder’s tape measures. They allow the entire structure to collapse to a diameter of just 75 cm. This wrapped‑rib design dramatically reduces the volume the 140-kilogram CarbSAR satellite would otherwise occupy at the top of its rocket.

Once released into orbit, the strain energy stored in the bent carbon fibre drives the ribs to snap back into a straightened configuration, pulling the mesh into place to form the parabolic dish.

“But for the imaging we want to do, we also need to unfurl with precision – to get that perfect parabolic shape,” says Sean Sutcliffe, OSS’s chief executive. “And that’s the beauty of our design.” Testing shows that, across the antenna, the mesh sheets remain within a millimetre of the ideal shape.

Earth observation with small radar satellites is booming. The technology’s ability to image the ground in all weather conditions, and even at night, has been championed by a slew of new space companies.

Their data has found particular favour with militaries around the world and has played a major intelligence role in the Russia-Ukraine war.

But despite leading the development of space radar in Europe in the 1990s, the UK has largely been left behind by international competition.

CarbSAR, and a future MoD constellation called Oberon – which is part of a broader programme named ISTARI – offer British aerospace engineers a chance to reassert themselves.

“We’re getting a lot of interest from foreign governments about the possibility of providing a radar concept for them,” says Andrew Cawthorne, SSTL’s managing director. “Obviously, the first thing we need to do is deploy this antenna and prove we can take an image.”

The expectation is that CarbSAR will see objects down to about 50 cm in size, which is more than sufficient to make out tanks and planes.

When the antenna is deployed about two days after launch, UK Space Command – which is overseen by the Royal Air Force – will be watching closely.

“CarbSAR is a testament to the innovation and collaboration of one of the UK’s most forward‑thinking space companies,” says Major General Paul Tedman, commander of UK Space Command.

“Space Command is excited to see CarbSAR in action and to explore how its advanced instruments can be integrated into Oberon and our wider ISTARI satellite programme.”
articles.reasoning: The article describes a novel technological innovation in satellite design using an industrial knitting machine to produce a radar antenna mesh, enabling a compact, deployable satellite dish for Earth observation. This advancement has significant implications for space technology and Earth monitoring, with potential broad benefits including enhanced imaging capabilities in all weather conditions and national security applications. The story is focused, detailed, and highlights a meaningful breakthrough in satellite engineering with expected large-scale impact.
articles.personality_title: UK’s knitted satellite set to capture detailed radar images of Earth
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – A new UK satellite named CarbSAR is about to launch with a special radar antenna made using an unusual method. Instead of traditional manufacturing, the antenna is created using a modified knitting machine.

**What happened** – Oxford Space Systems (OSS) changed a regular knitting machine to weave fabric from thin tungsten wires coated in gold. This fabric forms a large, flexible dish that folds up small for launch and unfolds in space to capture radar images. CarbSAR will launch soon and is designed to take clear pictures of Earth’s surface, even through clouds or at night.

**Impact** – This innovative design allows the satellite to be compact during launch and then expand to a precise shape needed for radar imaging. It is lighter and smaller than usual radar antennas, making it easier and cheaper to send into space. The technology could help the UK catch up in radar satellite development and support national security by spotting objects like tanks or planes from space.

**What’s next step** – CarbSAR will deploy its knitted antenna a few days after launch. UK Space Command will monitor its performance closely. If successful, this design will be used in a future group of satellites called Oberon, which will boost the UK’s ability to observe Earth from space.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A UK satellite using a knitted gold wire antenna will soon orbit Earth to provide detailed radar images, showing a new way to build advanced space technology.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le satellite tricoté du Royaume-Uni prêt à capturer des images radar détaillées de la Terre
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Un nouveau satellite britannique nommé CarbSAR s'apprête à être lancé avec une antenne radar spéciale fabriquée d'une manière inhabituelle. Au lieu de méthodes traditionnelles, l'antenne est créée à l'aide d'une machine à tricoter modifiée.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Oxford Space Systems (OSS) a transformé une machine à tricoter ordinaire pour tisser un tissu à partir de fils fins de tungstène recouverts d'or. Ce tissu forme un grand miroir flexible qui se replie pour le lancement et se déploie dans l'espace pour capturer des images radar. CarbSAR va bientôt être lancé et est conçu pour prendre des images claires de la surface de la Terre, même à travers les nuages ou la nuit.

**Impact** – Ce design innovant permet au satellite d'être compact au lancement puis de s'étendre en une forme précise nécessaire pour l'imagerie radar. Il est plus léger et plus petit que les antennes radar habituelles, ce qui facilite et réduit le coût de son envoi dans l'espace. Cette technologie pourrait aider le Royaume-Uni à rattraper son retard dans le développement des satellites radar et à renforcer la sécurité nationale en repérant des objets comme des chars ou des avions depuis l'espace.

**Prochaine étape** – CarbSAR déploiera son antenne tricotée quelques jours après le lancement. Le Commandement spatial britannique surveillera de près ses performances. Si le test est concluant, ce design sera utilisé dans un futur groupe de satellites appelé Oberon, qui améliorera la capacité du Royaume-Uni à observer la Terre depuis l'espace.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Un satellite britannique utilisant une antenne en fil d'or tricoté va bientôt orbiter autour de la Terre pour fournir des images radar détaillées, montrant une nouvelle façon de construire des technologies spatiales avancées.
articles.personality_title_es: El satélite tejido del Reino Unido listo para capturar imágenes radar detalladas de la Tierra
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Un nuevo satélite del Reino Unido llamado CarbSAR está a punto de ser lanzado con una antena radar especial fabricada de una manera poco común. En lugar de métodos tradicionales, la antena se crea usando una máquina de tejer modificada.

**Qué pasó** – Oxford Space Systems (OSS) cambió una máquina de tejer común para crear una tela con hilos finos de tungsteno recubiertos de oro. Esta tela forma un gran plato flexible que se pliega para el lanzamiento y se despliega en el espacio para capturar imágenes radar. CarbSAR se lanzará pronto y está diseñado para tomar imágenes claras de la superficie de la Tierra, incluso a través de nubes o de noche.

**Impacto** – Este diseño innovador permite que el satélite sea compacto durante el lanzamiento y luego se expanda a una forma precisa necesaria para la imagen radar. Es más ligero y pequeño que las antenas radar habituales, lo que facilita y abarata su envío al espacio. Esta tecnología podría ayudar al Reino Unido a ponerse al día en el desarrollo de satélites radar y apoyar la seguridad nacional al detectar objetos como tanques o aviones desde el espacio.

**Próximo paso** – CarbSAR desplegará su antena tejida pocos días después del lanzamiento. El Comando Espacial del Reino Unido seguirá de cerca su desempeño. Si tiene éxito, este diseño se usará en un futuro grupo de satélites llamado Oberon, que mejorará la capacidad del Reino Unido para observar la Tierra desde el espacio.

**Resumen en una frase** – Un satélite británico que usa una antena de hilo de oro tejido pronto orbitará la Tierra para ofrecer imágenes radar detalladas, mostrando una nueva forma de construir tecnología espacial avanzada.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed painting of a delicate golden tungsten wire mesh being intricately knitted by an industrial knitting machine’s stylized needles, transforming into a large, elegant parabolic satellite dish with carbon-fiber ribs unfolding like coiled tape measures against a softly glowing Earth backdrop, rendered in warm, natural tones with a focus on craftsmanship and innovative engineering.
